1.verse: Paul, a servant of Christ Jesus, called to be an apostle, set apart for the gospel of God,

2.verse: which he promised beforehand through his prophets in the holy scriptures,

3.verse: the gospel concerning his Son, who was descended from David according to the flesh,

4.verse: and was designated Son of God with power according to the spirit of holiness by the resurrection from the dead, Jesus Christ our Lord.

5.verse: Through him we have received grace and apostleship to bring about the obedience of faith among all the nations on behalf of his name,

6.verse: among whom are you also, called to belong to Jesus Christ.

7.verse: To all who are in Rome, loved by God and called to be saints: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

8.verse: First of all, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for all of you, because your faith is being proclaimed throughout the whole world.

9.verse: For God is my witness, whom I serve with my spirit in the gospel of his Son, how unceasingly I make mention of you

10.verse: always in my prayers, asking if perhaps now at last I may be able, by the will of God, to visit you.

11.verse: For I long to see you so that I may share with you some spiritual gift to strengthen you—

12.verse: that is, that we may be mutually encouraged by each other’s faith, I by yours and you by mine.

13.verse: I do not want you to be unaware, brethren, that I often intended to come to you (but have been prevented until now) so that I might have some fruit among you, just as among the rest of the Gentiles.

14.verse: I am a debtor both to the Greeks and to the barbarians, to the wise as well as to the foolish.

15.verse: So for my part I am eager to preach the gospel to you also who are in Rome.

16.verse: For I am not ashamed of the gospel; it is the power of God for salvation to everyone who believes, to the Jew first and also to the Greek.

17.verse: For in it the righteousness of God is revealed from faith to faith; as it is written, “The righteous by faith will live.”

18.verse: For the wrath of God is being revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and the unrighteousness of those who suppress the truth by their unrighteousness,

19.verse: because what can be known about God is plain to them, for God has revealed it to them.

20.verse: Ever since the creation of the world, his invisible attributes, that is, his eternal power and divine nature, have been clearly seen, being understood through what has been made. So they are without excuse.

21.verse: Even though they knew God, they did not honor him as God or give him thanks, but they became futile in their speculations and their foolish hearts were darkened.

22.verse: Professing to be wise, they became fools,

23.verse: and exchanged the glory of the incorruptible God for images resembling corruptible man and birds and four-footed animals and crawling creatures.

24.verse: Therefore God gave them over in the lusts of their hearts to impurity, so that they dishonored their bodies among themselves.

25.verse: They exchanged the truth of God for a lie and worshiped and served the creature rather than the Creator, who is blessed for all time. Amen.

26.verse: For this reason God gave them over to degrading passions. Their women exchanged the natural sexual function for one that is unnatural,

27.verse: and likewise the men also abandoned the natural sexual relation with women and burned in their passion for one another—men with men committing shameless acts and receiving in themselves the due penalty for their error.

28.verse: And as they did not see fit to acknowledge God, God gave them over to a debased mind, to do things that ought not to be done.

29.verse: They are filled with every kind of unrighteousness, wickedness, covetousness, malice. They are full of envy, murder, strife, deceit, meanness. They are gossips,

30.verse: slanderers, haters of God, insolent, arrogant, boastful, inventors of evil, disobedient to parents,

32.verse: Though they understand the righteous requirement of God, that those who practice such things are worthy of death, they not only continue to do them but also to heartily approve of others who practice them.

1.verse: Therefore you are without excuse, whoever you are, when you judge someone else, for in that which you judge another, you condemn yourself, for you who judge are practicing the same things.

2.verse: And we know that the judgment of God is according to truth with respect to those who practice such things.

3.verse: Do you suppose, this, whoever you are, when you judge those who practice such things yet do them yourself, that you will escape the judgment of God?

4.verse: Or do you hold in contempt the riches of his kindness and forbearance and patience, not knowing that God’s kindness is meant to lead you to repentance?

5.verse: But because of your stubbornness and your unrepentant heart, you are storing up wrath for yourself on the day of wrath, when God’s righteous judgment will be revealed,

6.verse: who will give to each person according to what he has done:

7.verse: to those who by patiently doing good works seek for glory and honor and immortality, he will give eternal life;

8.verse: but to those who are self-seeking and do not obey the truth but obey unrighteousness, there will be wrath and fury.

9.verse: There will be tribulation and distress for every human being who does evil, for the Jew first and also for the Greek,

10.verse: but glory and honor and peace for everyone who does good, for the Jew first and also for the Greek.

11.verse: For there is no favoritism with God:

12.verse: for all who have sinned apart from the law will also perish apart from the law, and all who have sinned under the law will be judged by the law;

13.verse: for it is not the hearers of the law who are righteous before God, but the doers of the law who will be declared righteous.

14.verse: For whenever the Gentiles, who do not have the law, do by nature the things required by the law, these, although they do not have the law, are a law to themselves.

15.verse: They show that the work of the law is written on their hearts, their conscience bearing witness and their conflicting thoughts accusing or else defending them,

16.verse: on the day when God judges the secrets of everyone according to my gospel through Christ Jesus.

17.verse: But if you call yourself a Jew, and rely on the law, and boast in God,

18.verse: and know his will, and approve the things that excel because you are instructed by the law,

19.verse: and are convinced that you yourself are a guide of the blind, a light for those who are in darkness,

20.verse: a corrector of the foolish, a teacher of little children, having in the law the embodiment of knowledge and of truth—

21.verse: you, then, who teach others, will you not teach yourself? You who preach against stealing, do you steal?

22.verse: You who tell others not to commit adultery, do you commit adultery? You who abhor idols, do you rob temples?

23.verse: You who boast in the law, by your breaking of the law you dishonor God!

24.verse: For as it is written, “On account of you the name of God is being blasphemed among the Gentiles.”

25.verse: For to be sure, circumcision is of value if you practice the law, but if you are a transgressor of the law, your circumcision has become uncircumcision.

26.verse: Therefore if the uncircumcised man keeps the righteous requirements of the law, will not his uncircumcision be counted as circumcision?

27.verse: And will not the one who by nature is uncircumcised yet fulfills the law judge you who have the written code and circumcision yet are a transgressor of the law?

28.verse: For that person is not a Jew who is one outwardly, nor is circumcision that which is outward in the flesh.

29.verse: But a person is a Jew who is one inwardly, and circumcision is a matter of the heart, by the Spirit and not by the written code. That person’s praise comes not from man but from God.

1.verse: What advantage then has the Jew? Or what is the value of circumcision?

2.verse: Much in every way. For first of all, they were entrusted with the oracles of God.

3.verse: But what if some were unfaithful, will their lack of faith nullify the faithfulness of God?

4.verse: By no means! Let God be true and every man a liar. As it is written, “so that you may be justified in your words and prevail when you are judged.”

5.verse: But if our unrighteousness demonstrates the righteousness of God, what shall we say? That God is unjust to inflict wrath on us? (I use a human argument!)

6.verse: By no means! For otherwise how could God judge the world?

7.verse: But if by my lie God’s truthfulness abounds to his glory, why am I still being condemned as a sinner?

8.verse: And why not say (as some slanderously claim that we are saying), “Let us do evil so that good may come of it”? Their condemnation is well deserved!

9.verse: What then? Are we better off? Not at all, for we have already charged that both Jews and Greeks are all under the power of sin,

10.verse: as it is written, “No one is righteous, not even one;

11.verse: no one is understanding; no one is seeking for God.

12.verse: They have all turned away; together they have become worthless. No one is doing good, there is not even one.

13.verse: Their throat is an open grave; with their tongues they deceive; the poison of asps is under their lips;

14.verse: their mouth is full of cursing and bitterness;

15.verse: their feet are swift to shed blood;

16.verse: destruction and misery are in their paths;

17.verse: and the way of peace they have not known.

18.verse: There is no fear of God before their eyes.”

19.verse: Now we know that whatever the law says, it speaks to those who are under the law, so that every mouth may be silenced and the whole world may be held accountable to God.

20.verse: So by the works of the law no flesh at all will be justified before him, because through the law comes the knowledge of sin.

21.verse: But now, apart from the law (although attested by the law and the prophets) the righteousness of God has been disclosed.

22.verse: It is the righteousness of God available through faith in Jesus Christ for all who believe. (For there is no distinction,

23.verse: since all have sinned and continue to fall short of the glory of God.)

24.verse: They are justified freely by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus,

25.verse: whom God set forth as an atoning sacrifice by his blood, obtainable through faith. This was to demonstrate his righteousness, because God in his forbearance had passed over previous sins.

26.verse: It was also to demonstrate his righteousness at the present time, that he might be just and the justifier of the one who has faith in Jesus.

27.verse: Where then is boasting? It has been excluded. By what kind of law? By a law of works? No, but by the law of faith.

28.verse: For we hold that a person is justified by faith apart from the works of the law.

29.verse: Or is God the God of Jews only? Is he not the God of Gentiles as well? Yes, of Gentiles as well.

30.verse: Since God is one, he will justify the circumcised on the basis of their faith and the uncircumcised by the same faith.

31.verse: Do we therefore nullify the law through faith? By no means! On the contrary, we uphold the law.

1.verse: What then shall we say that Abraham, our forefather according to the flesh, has discovered about this?

2.verse: For if Abraham was justified by works, he has something to boast about (but not before God).

3.verse: For what does the scripture say? “And Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness.”

4.verse: Now to the one who works, his wages are not credited as a gift, but as an obligation.

5.verse: But to the one who does not work, but entrusts himself to the one who justifies the ungodly, his faith is credited as righteousness.

6.verse: So also David speaks of the blessedness of the one to whom God credits righteousness apart from works:

7.verse: “Blessed are those whose lawless deeds are forgiven, and whose sins are covered.

8.verse: Blessed is the man whose sin the Lord will not take into account.”

9.verse: Therefore, is this blessedness for the circumcised alone, or is it also for the uncircumcised? For we say, “It was to Abraham that faith was credited as righteousness.”

10.verse: How then was it credited to him? Was it after he was circumcised or before? It was not after his circumcision but before.

11.verse: He received the sign of circumcision as a seal of the righteousness that he had by faith while he was still uncircumcised, so that he would be the father of all who believe but have never been circumcised, that they too might have righteousness credited to them.

12.verse: He is also the father of the circumcised who are not merely circumcised but also walk in the footsteps of the faith that our father Abraham had while he was still uncircumcised.

13.verse: For the promise that he would be heir of the world did not come to Abraham or to his descendants through the law, but through the righteousness of faith.

14.verse: For if the heirs are those who follow the law, then faith is meaningless and the promise is void.

15.verse: For the Law brings about wrath, but where there is no law, there can be no violation.

16.verse: For this reason the promise is based on faith, that it may depend on grace and so that it may be made certain to all his descendants, not only to those who are under the law, but also to those who share the faith of Abraham, who is the father of us all.

17.verse: As it is written, “I have made you the father of many nations.” He is our father, in the presence of God in whom he believed, the God who gives life to the dead and calls into being the things that do not exist.

18.verse: Hoping against hope, Abraham believed that he would become the father of many nations according to what had been spoken, “So will your descendants be.”

19.verse: Not being weak in faith, he considered his own body as dead (since he was about a hundred years old), and the barrenness of Sarah’s womb.

20.verse: He did not waver in unbelief regarding the promise of God but was strengthened in faith, giving glory to God,

21.verse: fully convinced that what God had promised, he was also able to do.

22.verse: That is why his faith was credited to him as righteousness.

23.verse: But the statement, “it was credited to him,” was not written for his sake alone,

24.verse: but for our sake as well, to whom it will be credited, those who believe in the one who raised Jesus our Lord from the dead,

25.verse: who was delivered over to death for our transgressions and raised for our justification.

1.verse: Therefore, since we are justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ,

2.verse: through whom we have also obtained access by faith into this grace in which we stand, and we rejoice in hope of sharing the glory of God.

3.verse: And not only that, but we also rejoice in our sufferings, knowing that suffering produces endurance,

4.verse: and endurance produces character, and character produces hope,

5.verse: and hope does not disappoint us, because the love of God has been poured out into our hearts through the Holy Spirit who was given to us.

6.verse: For while we were still helpless, at the right time Christ died for the ungodly.

7.verse: For rarely will one die for an upright person—though perhaps for a genuinely good person one might actually dare to die.

8.verse: But God demonstrates his love for us in that while we were still sinners Christ died for us.

9.verse: Since we have now been justified by his blood, much more will we be saved from the wrath of God through him.

10.verse: For if while we were enemies we were reconciled to God through the death of his Son, much more, now that we are reconciled, will we be saved by his life.

11.verse: And not only that, but we also rejoice in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we now have received reconciliation.

12.verse: Therefore, just as sin came into the world through one man, and death through sin, and so death spread to all men, because all have sinned—.

13.verse: For sin was in the world before the law was given, but sin is not charged when there is no law.

14.verse: Nevertheless death reigned from Adam until Moses, even over those whose sinning was not like the transgression of Adam, who was a type of the coming one.

15.verse: But the free gift is not like the transgression. For if the many died through the transgression of the one, much more did the grace of God and the gift that came by the grace of the one man Jesus Christ overflow to the many.

16.verse: And the gift is not like the result of that one man’s sin; for the judgment following the one transgression led to condemnation, but the free gift following the many transgressions led to justification.

17.verse: For if by the transgression of the one man death reigned through that one, much more will those who receive the abundance of grace and the gift of righteousness reign in life through the one, Jesus Christ.

18.verse: Therefore, just as one man’s transgression brought condemnation for all men, so also one man’s righteous act brought justification and life for all men.

19.verse: For just as through one man’s disobedience the many were made sinners, so also through the one man’s obedience the many will be made righteous.

20.verse: Now the law came in so that the transgression might increase; but where sin increased, grace increased all the more,

21.verse: so that just as sin reigned in death, so also grace might reign through righteousness leading to eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.

1.verse: What then shall we say?—“Let us continue in sin so that grace may increase”?

2.verse: By no means! How can we who died to sin go on living in it?

3.verse: Or do you not know that we who were baptized into Christ Jesus were baptized into his death?

4.verse: Therefore we were buried with him by baptism into death, so that just as Christ was raised from the dead by the glory of the Father, so also we might walk in newness of life.

5.verse: For if we have become united with him in the likeness of his death, we will certainly also be united with him in the likeness of his resurrection.

6.verse: We know this, that our old self was crucified with him, so that the body of sin would be rendered powerless, so that we would no longer be enslaved by sin;

7.verse: for the one who has died has been set free from sin.

8.verse: Now if we have died with Christ, we believe that we will also live with him.

9.verse: We know that Christ, having been raised from the dead, will never die again; death no longer has mastery over him.

10.verse: For the death he died, he died to sin once for all; but the life he lives, he lives to God.

11.verse: So you too consider yourselves to be dead to sin but alive to God in Christ Jesus.

12.verse: Therefore do not let sin reign in your mortal body so that you obey its desires.

13.verse: Do not continue to present your members to sin as instruments for unrighteousness, but present yourselves to God as alive from the dead, and your members to God as instruments for righteousness.

14.verse: For sin will not have mastery over you, since you are not under law but under grace.

15.verse: What then? Should we sin because we are not under law but under grace? By no means!

16.verse: Do you not know that if you present yourselves to someone as obedient slaves, you are slaves of the one whom you obey, either of sin, which leads to death, or of obedience, which leads to righteousness?

17.verse: But thanks be to God that though you were slaves of sin, you became obedient from the heart to that pattern of teaching to which you were committed,

18.verse: and having been set free from sin, you became slaves of righteousness.

19.verse: (I am speaking in human terms because of your natural limitations.) For just as you presented your members as slaves to impurity and to lawlessness leading to more lawlessness, so now present your members as slaves to righteousness, leading to sanctification.

20.verse: For when you were slaves of sin, you were free with regard to righteousness.

21.verse: Therefore what fruit were you getting at that time from the things of which you are now ashamed? For the end of those things is death.

22.verse: But now, freed from sin and enslaved to God, the fruit you get leads to sanctification, and its outcome, eternal life.

23.verse: For the wages of sin is death, but the free gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.

1.verse: Or do you not know, brethren (for I am speaking to those who know the law), that the law is binding on a person only so long as he lives?

2.verse: Thus a married woman is bound by law to her husband while he is living; but if her husband dies, she is released from the law of marriage.

3.verse: Accordingly, if she is joined to another man while her husband is alive, she will be called an adulteress; but if her husband dies, she is free from that law, so that she is not an adulteress if she marries another man.

4.verse: So then, my brothers, you also have died to the law through the body of Christ that you might belong to another, to the one who was raised from the dead, so that we might bear fruit for God.

5.verse: For while we were living in the flesh, our sinful passions, aroused by the law, were at work in our bodies to bear fruit for death.

6.verse: But now we have been released from the law, having died to that which held us captive, so that we serve in newness of the Spirit and not under the old written code.

7.verse: What then shall we say? Is the law sin? By no means! On the contrary, I would not have known sin except through the law; that is, I would not have known what it means to covet had not the law said, “You shall not covet.”

8.verse: But sin, seizing the opportunity through the commandment, produced in me all kinds of covetousness. (For apart from the law, sin is dead.)

9.verse: I was once alive apart from the law, but when the commandment came, sin came to life

10.verse: and I died. I found that the very commandment that promised life brought death to me!

11.verse: For sin, seizing the opportunity through the commandment, deceived me and through it killed me.

12.verse: So then, the law is holy, and the commandment is holy and righteous and good.

13.verse: Did that which is good, then, become death to me? By no means! But sin, in order that it might be shown to be sin, produced death in me through that which is good so that sin, through the commandment, might be sinful beyond measure

14.verse: For we know that the law is spiritual; but I am unspiritual, sold as a slave to sin.

15.verse: For I do not understand my own actions; for I am not doing what I want to do, but I am doing what I hate.

16.verse: But if I am doing what I do not want to do, I agree with the law, that it is good.

17.verse: So now it is no longer I myself doing it, but sin living in me.

18.verse: For I know that nothing good dwells in me, that is, in my flesh; for I have the desire to do what is right, but I am unable to do it.

19.verse: For I do not do the good I want, but the evil I do not want is what I do.

20.verse: Now if I do what I do not want, it is no longer I who do it, but sin that lives in me.

21.verse: So I find it to be a law that when I want to do good, evil is present in me.

22.verse: For I joyfully agree with the law of God in the inner man,

23.verse: but I see a different law in my members; it wages war against the law of my mind and makes me captive to the law of sin dwelling in my members.

24.verse: Wretched man that I am! Who will deliver me from this body of death?

25.verse: Thanks be to God through Jesus Christ our Lord! So then, I myself serve the law of God with my mind, but with my flesh I serve the law of sin.

1.verse: There is therefore now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus.

2.verse: For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus has set you free from the law of sin and of death.

3.verse: For what the law could not do, weak as it was through the flesh, God, by sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh and as a sin offering, condemned sin in the flesh,

4.verse: so that the righteous requirement of the law might be fulfilled in us, who do not walk according to the flesh but according to the Spirit.

5.verse: For those who live according to the flesh have set their minds on the things of the flesh, but those who live according to the Spirit have set their minds on the things of the Spirit.

6.verse: To set the mind on the flesh leads to death, but to set the mind on the Spirit brings life and peace,

7.verse: because the mind set on the flesh is hostile to God; it does not submit to the law of God; in fact, it is not even able to do so.

8.verse: Those controlled by the flesh are not able to please God.

9.verse: You, however, are not controlled by the flesh but by the Spirit, if indeed the Spirit of God lives in you. Whoever does not have the Spirit of Christ does not belong to him.

10.verse: But if Christ is in you, although the body is dead because of sin, the Spirit is life because of righteousness.

11.verse: But if the Spirit of him who raised Jesus from the dead lives in you, the one who raised Christ Jesus from the dead will also give life to your mortal bodies through his Spirit who lives in you.

12.verse: So then, brethren, we are debtors, not to the flesh, to live according to the flesh,

13.verse: for if you live according to the flesh, you will certainly die; but if by the Spirit you put to death the deeds of the body, you will live.

14.verse: For it is those who are led by the Spirit of God who are the sons of God.

15.verse: For you did not receive the spirit of slavery leading back to fear, but you received the Spirit of adoption. By him we cry out, “Abba! Father!”

16.verse: The Spirit himself bears witness with our spirit that we are children of God,

17.verse: and if children, then heirs, heirs of God and fellow heirs with Christ, provided we suffer with him so that we may also be glorified with him.

18.verse: For I consider that the sufferings of this present time are not worth comparing with the glory that will be revealed to us.

19.verse: For the creation eagerly waits for the revealing of the sons of God.

20.verse: For the creation was subjected to futility, not of its own choosing, but because of him who subjected it, in hope

21.verse: that the creation itself will be set free from its bondage to decay into the glorious freedom of the children of God.

22.verse: For we know that the entire creation has been groaning and suffering together up to the present hour.

23.verse: And not only this, but we ourselves, who have the first fruits of the Spirit, groan inwardly as we eagerly await our adoption, the redemption of our bodies.

24.verse: For in this hope we were saved. Now hope that is seen is not hope, for who hopes for what he sees?

25.verse: But if we hope for what we do not see, we wait for it with patience.

26.verse: In the same way, the Spirit helps us in our weakness; for we do not know how to pray as we ought, but the Spirit himself intercedes for us with groanings too deep for words.

27.verse: And God, who searches our hearts, knows the desire of the Spirit, because the Spirit intercedes for the saints according to the will of God.

28.verse: And we know that all things work together for good for those who love God, for those who are called according to his purpose,

29.verse: because those he foreknew he also predestined to become conformed to the image of his Son, that he might be the firstborn among many brethren.

30.verse: And those he predestined, these he also called; and those he called, these he also justified; and those he justified, these he also glorified.

31.verse: What then shall we say in response to these things? If God is for us, who can be against us?

32.verse: He who did not spare his own Son, but delivered him up for us all, how will he not also, along with him, graciously give us all things?

33.verse: Who will bring a charge against God’s elect? It is God who justifies.

34.verse: Who is it that condemns? Christ Jesus is the one who died—and more than that, he was raised—who is at the right hand of God, who also is interceding for us.

35.verse: Who can separate us from the love of Christ? Can tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or danger, or sword?

36.verse: As it is written, “For your sake we face death all day long; we are regarded as sheep to be slaughtered.”

37.verse: No, in all these things we are winning a most glorious victory through him who loved us.

38.verse: For I am convinced that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor rulers, nor things present, nor things to come, nor powers,

39.verse: nor height, nor depth, nor any other created thing will be able to separate us from the love of God in Christ Jesus our Lord.

1.verse: I am telling the truth in Christ—I am not lying; my conscience bears witness with me in the Holy Spirit—

2.verse: that I have great sorrow and unceasing anguish in my heart.

3.verse: For I could wish that I myself were accursed, cut off from Christ, for the sake of my brethren, my kinsmen according to the flesh,

4.verse: who are Israelites. To them belong the adoption, the glory, the covenants, the giving of the law, the temple worship, and the promises.

5.verse: To them belong the patriarchs, and from them by human descent came the Christ, who is God over all, blessed for all time. Amen.

6.verse: But it is not as though the word of God had failed. For not all who are descended from Israel are actually Israel;

7.verse: neither are they all children of Abraham because they are his descendants; on the contrary, “It is through Isaac that your descendants will be named.”

8.verse: This means it is not the children of the flesh who are children of God, but the children of the promise are counted as descendants.

9.verse: For this is what the promise said: “About this time next year I will return and Sarah will have a son.”

10.verse: Not only that, but when Rebecca had conceived twins by one man, our forefather Isaac—

11.verse: for even before they were born or had done anything either good or bad so that God’s purpose according to election might stand,

12.verse: not because of works, but because of his call—it was said to her, “The older will serve the younger.”

13.verse: As it is written, “Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated.”

14.verse: What then shall we say? Is there not injustice on God’s part? By no means!

15.verse: For he says to Moses, “I will have mercy on whom I have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I have compassion.”

16.verse: So then, it does not depend on human desire or exertion, but on God’s mercy.

17.verse: For the scripture says to Pharaoh, “For this very purpose I have raised you up, that I might display my power in you, and that my name might be proclaimed in all the earth.”

18.verse: So then, God has mercy on whomever he wills, and he hardens whomever he wills.

19.verse: So you will say to me, “Why then does he still find fault? For who can resist his will?”

20.verse: But who are you, a mere mortal, to criticize God? Certainly the thing that is molded may not say to the one who molded it, “Why have you made me like this?”

21.verse: Has the potter no right to make from the same lump of clay some pottery for a special occasion and other for common use?

22.verse: What if God, willing to display his wrath and make known his power, has endured with great patience the objects of wrath prepared for destruction?

23.verse: And what if he did so in order to make known the riches of his glory to the objects of mercy, which he prepared beforehand for glory—

24.verse: even us, whom he has called, not only from the Jews, but also from the Gentiles.

25.verse: As he also says in Hosea, “Those who were not my people, I will call ‘my people,’ and her who was not beloved, I will call ‘beloved.’”

26.verse: “And it will happen that in the very place where God said to them, ‘You are not my people,’ there they will be called ‘sons of the living God.’”

27.verse: Isaiah cries out concerning Israel, “Even if the number of the sons of Israel were as the sand of the sea, only a remnant will be saved;

28.verse: for the Lord will carry out his sentence on the earth, thoroughly and without delay.”

29.verse: And as Isaiah predicted, “If the Lord of hosts had not left to us descendants, we would have become like Sodom, and would have resembled Gomorrah.”

30.verse: What then shall we say?—that the Gentiles who did not pursue righteousness have obtained it, the righteousness that is by faith;

31.verse: but Israel, even though it pursued a law that would produce righteousness, did not attain it?

32.verse: Why not? Because they did not pursue it by faith, but as though it were by works. They stumbled over the stumbling stone,

33.verse: as it is written, “Behold, I am laying in Zion a stone that makes them stumble and a rock that trips them up; but the one who believes in him will not be put to shame.”

1.verse: Brethren, my heart’s desire and prayer to God for the Israelites is that they may be saved.

2.verse: For I bear them witness that they have a zeal for God, but not according to knowledge.

3.verse: For ignoring the righteousness that comes from God, and seeking to establish their own, they did not submit to God’s righteousness.

4.verse: For Christ is the end of the law, so now there is righteousness for everyone who believes.

5.verse: For Moses writes regarding the righteousness that is based on the law, “The person committed to these things must live by them.”

6.verse: But the righteousness based on faith says, “Do not say in your heart, ‘Who will ascend into heaven?’ (that is, to bring Christ down),

7.verse: or, ‘Who will descend into the abyss?’ (that is, to bring Christ up from the dead).”

8.verse: But what does it say? “The word is near you, in your mouth and in your heart,” that is, the word of faith that we proclaim:

9.verse: that if you confess with your mouth, “Jesus is Lord,” and believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead, you will be saved.

10.verse: For with the heart a person believes and is made righteous, and with the mouth he confesses and is saved.

11.verse: For the Scripture says, “Whoever believes in him will not be put to shame.”

12.verse: For there is no distinction between the Jew and the Greek; for the same Lord is Lord of all, giving generously to all who call on him;

13.verse: for “everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.”

14.verse: But how are they to call on one in whom they have not believed? And how are they to believe in one of whom they have never heard? And how are they to hear unless someone proclaims the message?

15.verse: And how are they to proclaim the message unless they are sent? As it is written, “How timely are the feet of those who preach good news!”

16.verse: However, not all of them have obeyed the good news, for Isaiah says, “Lord, who has believed our message?”

17.verse: So faith comes from hearing the message, and what is heard comes through the word of Christ.

18.verse: But I ask, have they not heard? Indeed they have, for, “Their voice has gone out to all the earth, and their words to the ends of the world.”

19.verse: But I ask, did Israel not understand? First of all, Moses says, “I will make you jealous by those who are not a nation; by a nation void of understanding I will make you angry.”

20.verse: Then Isaiah very boldly says, “I was found by those who were not looking for me; I became well known to those who were not asking for me.”

21.verse: But concerning Israel he says, “All day long I have held out my hands to a disobedient and argumentative people.”

1.verse: So I ask, has God repudiated his people? By no means! For I myself am an Israelite, a descendant of Abraham, from the tribe of Benjamin.

2.verse: God has not repudiated his people whom he foreknew. Or do you not know what the Scripture says in the passage about Elijah, how he pleads with God against Israel?

3.verse: “Lord, they have killed your prophets, they have torn down your altars, and I alone am left, and they are seeking my life.”

4.verse: But what was the divine reply saying to him? “I have kept for myself seven thousand men who have not bowed the knee to Baal.”

5.verse: So too at the present time there is a remnant, chosen by grace.

6.verse: And if it is by grace, it is no longer on the basis of works, otherwise grace would no longer be grace.

7.verse: What then? Israel failed to obtain what it was seeking, but the elect obtained it. The rest were hardened,

8.verse: as it is written, “God gave them a spirit of stupor, eyes that would not see and ears that would not hear, to this very day.”

9.verse: And David says, “May their table become a snare and a trap, a stumbling block and a retribution for them.

10.verse: May their eyes be darkened so they cannot see, and keep their backs constantly bent.”

11.verse: So I ask, did they stumble so as to fall? By no means! But because of their transgression salvation has come to the Gentiles so as to make Israel jealous.

12.verse: Now if their transgression means riches for the world and their failure means riches for the Gentiles, how much more will their full inclusion mean!

13.verse: I am speaking to you Gentiles. Inasmuch then as I am an apostle to the Gentiles, I take pride in my ministry,

14.verse: if somehow I could provoke my own countrymen to jealousy and save some of them.

15.verse: For if their rejection leads to the reconciliation of the world, what will their acceptance mean but life from the dead?

16.verse: If the dough offered as first fruits is holy, so also is the whole lump; and if the root is holy, so also are the branches.

17.verse: But if some of the branches were broken off, and you, although a wild olive shoot, were grafted in among the others and you now share in the nourishing root of the olive tree,

18.verse: do not become arrogant toward the branches. But if you do, consider this: it is not you who support the root, but the root that supports you.

19.verse: Then you will say, “The branches were broken off so I could be grafted in.”

20.verse: That is true. They were broken off because of unbelief, and you stand by faith. Do not be proud, but stand in awe.

21.verse: For if God did not spare the natural branches, perhaps he will not spare you either.

22.verse: Consider therefore the kindness and the severity of God—severity to those who have fallen, but God’s kindness to you, provided you continue in his kindness. Otherwise you too will be cut off.

23.verse: And even they, if they do not continue in their unbelief, will be grafted in, for God is able to graft them in again.

24.verse: For if you were cut from what is by nature a wild olive tree, and grafted contrary to nature into a cultivated olive tree, how much more will these, the natural branches, be grafted back into their own olive tree?

25.verse: For I do not want you to be uninformed, my brothers, of this mystery—so that you may not be wise in your own conceits—that a partial hardening has happened to Israel until the full number of the Gentiles has come in.

26.verse: And in this way all Israel will be saved: as it is written, “Out of Zion will come the Deliverer; he will remove ungodliness from Jacob.”

27.verse: “And this will be my covenant with them, when I take away their sins.”

28.verse: In regard to the gospel they are enemies for your sake, but in regard to election they are dearly loved for the sake of their forefathers.

29.verse: For the gifts and the calling of God are irrevocable.

30.verse: For just as you were at one time disobedient to God but now have received mercy because of their disobedience,

31.verse: so they at the present time have been disobedient in order that by the mercy shown to you they also may now receive mercy.

32.verse: For God has consigned all to disobedience so that he may show mercy to all.

33.verse: O the depth of the riches and wisdom and knowledge of God! How unsearchable are his judgments and how inscrutable his ways!

34.verse: For who has known the mind of the Lord, or who has been his counselor?

35.verse: Or who has given to God that God must pay him back?

36.verse: For from him and through him and to him are all things. To him be glory for all time! Amen.

1.verse: I appeal to you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, to present your bodies as a living sacrifice, holy and acceptable to God—this is a reasonable act of worship for you.

2.verse: And do not be conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind, so that you may discern the will of God, what is good and acceptable and perfect.

3.verse: For by the grace given to me I say to every one who is among you that he should not think of himself more highly than he ought to think; but to think with sober judgment, as God has assigned to each a measure of faith.

4.verse: For as in our one body we have many members, and the members do not all have the same function,

5.verse: so we who are many are one body in Christ, and individually members who belong to one another,

6.verse: having gifts that differ according to the grace given to us. If your gift is prophecy, then prophesy in proportion to your faith;

7.verse: if your gift is service, use it to serve; if you are a teacher, then teach;

8.verse: if you have the gift of encouragement, then use it to encourage; if you are able to give, give generously; if your gift is leadership, lead with zeal; if it is showing mercy, then do it with cheerfulness.

9.verse: Let love be genuine. Abhor what is evil; hold fast to what is good.

10.verse: Love one another with brotherly affection; outdo one another in showing honor;

11.verse: do not lag in zeal; be enthusiastic in spirit; serve the Lord;

12.verse: rejoice in hope, be patient in suffering, devote yourself to prayer;

13.verse: contribute to the needs of the saints, seek to show hospitality.

14.verse: Bless those who persecute you; bless and do not curse them.

15.verse: Rejoice with those who rejoice; weep with those who weep.

16.verse: Live in harmony with one another; do not be haughty but associate with the lowly. Do not be wise in your own estimation.

17.verse: Repay no one evil for evil; give careful thought to what is good in the sight of all people.

18.verse: If possible, so far as it depends on you, be at peace with all people.

19.verse: Never avenge yourselves, dear friends, but leave room for the wrath of God, for it is written, “Vengeance is mine, I will repay, says the Lord.”

20.verse: To the contrary, “if your enemy is hungry, feed him; if he is thirsty, give him something to drink; for by doing this you will heap burning coals on his head.”

21.verse: Do not be overcome by evil, but overcome evil with good.

1.verse: Every person must be subject to the governing authorities because there is no authority except by God’s appointment, and those that presently exist have been instituted by God.

2.verse: Therefore whoever resists authority resists what God has decreed, and those who resist will bring judgment on themselves.

3.verse: For rulers are not a source of fear for those who do good, but for those who do wrong. Would you have no fear of the one in authority? Then do what is right and you will receive approval from him,

4.verse: for he is a servant of God for your good. But if you do what is wrong, be afraid; for he does not bear the sword in vain. For he is a servant of God, an avenger to carry out wrath on the one who does wrong.

5.verse: Therefore one must be subject, not only because of wrath, but also because of conscience.

6.verse: For this is also why you pay taxes, for authorities are servants of God, devoted to this very thing.

7.verse: Pay everyone what is owed to them: taxes to whom taxes are due; revenue to whom revenue is due; respect to whom respect is due; honor to whom honor is due.

8.verse: Owe no one anything, except to love one another; for the one who loves his neighbor has fulfilled the law.

9.verse: For the commandments, “You shall not commit adultery, You shall not murder, You shall not steal, You shall not covet,” (and any other commandment there may be) are summed up in this saying, “You shall love your neighbor as yourself.”

10.verse: Love does no wrong to its neighbor. Therefore love is the fulfillment of the law.

11.verse: And live this way because you are aware of the time, that the hour has come for us to wake from sleep, for our salvation is nearer now than when we first believed.

12.verse: The night is nearly over and the day is at hand. So we must lay aside the works of darkness and put on the armor of light.

13.verse: Let us live becomingly, as in the daytime, not in carousing and drunkenness, not in sexual promiscuity and sensuality, not in strife and jealousy.

14.verse: Rather, put on the Lord Jesus Christ, and make no provision for the sinful nature to gratify its desires.

1.verse: Accept the one who is weak in faith, but do not argue about his personal opinions.

2.verse: One person believes he can eat anything, while the weak brother eats only vegetables.

3.verse: The one who eats everything must not hold in contempt the one who does not eat, and the one who abstains from eating must not judge the one who eats, for God has accepted him.

4.verse: Who are you to pass judgment on someone else’s servant? It is before his own master that he will stand or fall. And he will stand, for the Lord is able to make him stand.

5.verse: For one person regards one day more sacred than another, while another person regards all days the same. Each person must be fully convinced in his own mind.

6.verse: The one who observes the day observes it for the Lord. And the one who eats, eats for the Lord, because he gives thanks to God; and the one who abstains from eating, does not eat for the Lord and gives thanks to God.

7.verse: For none of us lives for himself, and none dies for himself.

8.verse: For if we live, we live for the Lord, and if we die, we die for the Lord. So then, whether we live or whether we die, we belong to the Lord.

9.verse: For the reason why Christ died and rose to life again was that he might be Lord both of the dead and of the living.

10.verse: Why do you pass judgment on your brother? Or again, why do you hold your brother in contempt? For we will all stand before the judgment seat of God.

11.verse: For it is written, “As I live, says the Lord, every knee will bow to me, and every tongue will give praise to God.”

12.verse: So then each of us will give an account of himself to God.

13.verse: Therefore let us stop passing judgment on one another, but resolve this instead, never to put an obstacle or a trap in a brother’s way.

14.verse: I know and am convinced in the Lord Jesus that nothing is unclean in itself; however, to the one who considers something to be unclean, to him it is unclean.

15.verse: For if your brother is being hurt by what you eat, you are no longer walking in love. Do not destroy by what you eat that brother for whom Christ died.

16.verse: Therefore do not let what you regard as good be spoken of as evil.

17.verse: For the kingdom of God is not a matter of eating and drinking, but of righteousness and peace and joy in the Holy Spirit.

18.verse: For whoever serves Christ in this way is pleasing to God and approved by men.

19.verse: So then let us pursue what makes for peace and for mutual upbuilding.

20.verse: Do not, for the sake of food, destroy the work of God. All food is indeed clean, but it is wrong to cause another to stumble by what you eat.

21.verse: It is good not to eat meat or to drink wine or to do anything that makes your brother stumble.

22.verse: The faith that you have, keep as your own conviction before God. Blessed is the one who has no reason to condemn himself for what he approves.

23.verse: But the one who doubts is condemned if he eats, because his eating is not from faith; and whatever is not from faith is sin.

1.verse: We who are strong have an obligation to bear with the failings of the weak, and not to please ourselves.

2.verse: Let each of us please his neighbor for his good, to build him up.

3.verse: For Christ did not please himself; but as it is written, “The insults of those who insult you have fallen on me.”

4.verse: For whatever was written at an earlier time was written for our instruction, that through endurance and through the encouragement of the scriptures we might have hope.

5.verse: May the God of endurance and encouragement enable you to live in harmony with one another, according to Christ Jesus,

6.verse: so that together you may with one voice glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.

7.verse: Therefore accept one another even as Christ has also accepted you, for the glory of God.

8.verse: For I tell you that Christ has become a servant of the circumcised on behalf of the truth of God, in order to confirm the promises made to the patriarchs,

9.verse: and that the Gentiles might glorify God for his mercy. As it is written, “For this reason I will acknowledge you among the Gentiles and sing praises to your name.”

10.verse: And again it says, “Rejoice, O Gentiles, with his people.”

11.verse: And again, “Praise the Lord all you Gentiles, and let all the nations extol him.”

12.verse: And again Isaiah says, “The root of Jesse will come, even he who rises to rule over the Gentiles; in him will the Gentiles hope.”

13.verse: Now may the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, so that you may abound in hope by the power of the Holy Spirit.

14.verse: I myself am convinced about you, my brethren, that you yourselves are full of goodness, filled with all knowledge, and able also to instruct one another.

15.verse: Nevertheless on certain subjects I have written to you rather boldly so as to refresh your memory, because of the grace that was given me by God

16.verse: to be a minister of Christ Jesus to the Gentiles, serving the gospel of God as a priest, so that my offering of the Gentiles may become acceptable, sanctified by the Holy Spirit.

17.verse: In Christ Jesus, then, I have reason to boast of my work for God.

18.verse: For I will not venture to speak of anything except what Christ has accomplished through me in bringing the Gentiles to obedience, by word and deed,

19.verse: by the power of signs and wonders, by the power of the Spirit of God, so that from Jerusalem all the way around to Illyricum I have fulfilled my ministry of proclaiming the gospel of Christ.

20.verse: And thus I have always made it my aim to preach the gospel, not where Christ was known, lest I should build on someone else’s foundation;

21.verse: rather, as it is written, “Those who were not told of him will see, and those who have not heard of him will understand.”

22.verse: This is why on so many occasions I was kept from coming to you;

23.verse: but now I no longer have a reason for remaining in these regions, and for many years I have desired to come to visit you.

24.verse: When I do go to Spain, I hope to see you as I pass through and be helped on my way there by you, after I have enjoyed your company for a while.

25.verse: But for now, I am going to Jerusalem in a service for the saints.

26.verse: For Macedonia and Achaia were pleased to make a contribution to the poor among the saints in Jerusalem.

27.verse: They were pleased to do so, in fact, they are obligated to them; for if the Gentiles have come to share in their spiritual blessings, they ought also to be of service to them in material things.

28.verse: Therefore, when I have completed this task and have delivered to them what was raised, I will leave for Spain by way of you.

29.verse: And I know that when I come to you, I will come in the fulness of the blessing of Christ.

30.verse: Now I urge you, brethren, by our Lord Jesus Christ and by the love of the Spirit, to join me in fervent prayer to God on my behalf,

31.verse: that I may be delivered from those in Judea who refuse to believe, and that my service to Jerusalem may prove truly acceptable to the saints,

32.verse: so that by God’s will I may come to you with joy and be refreshed in your company.

33.verse: Now may the God of peace be with all of you. Amen.

1.verse: I commend to you our sister Phoebe, who is a servant of the church in Cenchrea,

2.verse: so that you may receive her in the Lord in a manner worthy of the saints, and give her any help she may need from you; for she has been of great assistance to many, including myself.

3.verse: Greet Prisca and Aquila, my fellow workers in Christ Jesus,

4.verse: who risked their own necks for my life. Not only I but also all the churches of the Gentiles are grateful to them.

5.verse: Also greet the church in their house. Greet my dear friend Epaenetus, who was the first convert to Christ in Asia.

6.verse: Greet Mary, who has worked so very hard for you.

7.verse: Greet Andronicus and Junia, my compatriots and my fellow prisoners; they were well known to the apostles, and they also were in Christ before me.

8.verse: Greet Ampliatus, my dear friend in the Lord.

9.verse: Greet Urbanus, our fellow worker in Christ, and my dear friend Stachys.

10.verse: Greet Apelles, a tried and true Christian. Greet those who belong to the household of Aristobulus.

11.verse: Greet Herodion, my compatriot. Greet those in the Lord who belong to the household of Narcissus.

12.verse: Greet Tryphaena and Tryphosa, diligent workers in the Lord. Greet my dear friend Persis, who has worked so very hard in the Lord.

13.verse: Greet Rufus, an outstanding Christian, also his mother and mine.

14.verse: Greet Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermes, Patrobas, Hermas, and the brethren with them.

15.verse: Greet Philologus and Julia, Nereus and his sister, and Olympas, and all the saints who are with them.

16.verse: Greet one another with a holy kiss. All the churches of Christ greet you.

17.verse: Now I urge you, brethren, to watch out for people who cause divisions and upset people’s faith contrary to the teaching that you have received. Avoid them.

18.verse: For such people do not serve our Lord Christ but their own appetites. By their smooth talk and flattery they deceive the hearts of the guileless.

19.verse: Your obedience is known to all and thus I am rejoicing over you. But I want you to be wise as to what is good, and innocent as to what is evil.

20.verse: The God of peace will soon crush Satan under your feet. May the grace of our Lord Jesus be with you.

21.verse: Timothy my fellow worker greets you, as do Lucius and Jason and Sosipater, my compatriots.

22.verse: I, Tertius, the one who is writing down this letter, greet you in the Lord.

23.verse: Gaius, a host to me as well as to the whole church, greets you. Erastus, the city treasurer greets you, as does our brother Quartus.

24.verse: verse doesn't exist in this bible version

25.verse: Now to him who is able to establish you according to my gospel and the preaching of Jesus Christ, according to the revelation of the mystery that has been kept secret for long ages past,

26.verse: but now is manifested, and by the Scriptures of the prophets, according to the commandment of the eternal God, has been made known to all the nations, leading to obedience of faith;

27.verse: to the only wise God, through Jesus Christ, be the glory for all time. Amen.
